It was beautiful in the country. It was summertime. The wheat was
yellow, the oats were green, the hay was stacked up in the green
meadows, and the stork paraded about on his long red legs, talking
in Egyptian, which language he had learnt from his mother.

The fields and meadows were skirted by thick woods, and a deep lake lay
in the midst of the woods. Yes; it was indeed beautiful in the country!
The sunshine fell warmly on an old mansion, surrounded by deep canals,
and from the walls down to the water's edge there grew large burdock
leaves, so high that children could stand upright among them without
being seen.

This place was as wild as the thickest part of the wood, and on that
account a Duck had chosen to make her nest there. She was sitting on
her eggs; but the pleasure she had felt at first was now almost gone,
because she had been there so long, and had so few visitors, for the
other Ducks preferred swimming on the canals to sitting among the
burdock leaves gossiping with her.

At last the eggs cracked one after another, "Chuckling--chuckling!"
as if they were very glad to be out of the eggshell. Well! she was
an industrious Duck, and she plucked and plaited her laces, so that
she might be just as nice as any of the other Ducks in the middle of
the water. Her brother and his wife had come with her, but when the
little ones hatched they had sailed away again. The mother Duck had
some of the eggs to lay a second time, for another brood, but the
young Ducks would not come near them. Then each family had its own
house, and they had nothing to do but live, and sing, and eat. The
duck, who was also called the duck of the pond, liked the other two
better than her son and daughter; for she was so nice herself that
the other ducks did not think of robbing her house.

Now all this while the Stork sat with his head down on his long
red legs, waiting until she should finish plaiting her laces, and
then, when she was quite tired, he would go across to her and tell
her that it was time to hatch the young Ducks. She said nothing,
for she was thinking of the young Ducklings, and she wished to have
some time alone with them.

After walking about all day he at last found the place to which he
had so frequently been obliged to return when he came to see his
friend the Duck. It stood on a green shelf which stuck out of the
pond into the woods, and from the old house a green bush of blossoms
was hanging down into the water. "The Duck," said the Stork, "may be
resting here, because she spends her time hanging on the blossoms."
Then he sat down, and whistled, and the mother Duck came flying from
her house. "What would you like to have? said the mother, as she
came to him. "If you were to come again, you might sit on the blossoms;
but as it seems as if you were tired already, and as you sit so close
to my house, it would be better not to ask what I have. Besides, if
you should see the little white things above me, you would be pained;
for the Stork's children have hatched." Then, with quick steps, he made
his way back towards his own home. He wished to collect in his mind
the images of the sweet young Ducks he would shortly see growing
up.

The sun was now setting, and as the Stork flew past the beautiful
vines, which hung down over the water, he stopped; the wind rose from
all directions round him, and the branches of the trees fluttered
and twisted, and in a moment it was altogether dark. The Stork had
two good pairs of eyes, as we know, and when he wished to see a thing
brightly, he struck it with his wing. He was a lonely old creature,
but he never felt lonely any longer, because when he saw the beautiful
Ducklings, his wife and children, floating off to the far shore, he
cried, "I too am going to live with you." And as he had wings which
could flutter and fly high up into the air, he flew away.

up. "No, not all, for the largest egg is still here. How long will this
last? I am so weary of it!" And then she sat down again.

"Well, and how are you getting on?" asked an old Duck, who had come to
pay her a visit.

"This one egg keeps me so long," said the mother. "It will not break.
But you should not stay too long in one place if you are weary of it.
You are not used to it. You ought to go a journey."

"I like this quiet corner of the woods to the meadows and the fields,"
said the old Duck, "and I like the canals with their reeds and bulrushes,
and the little birds that live on the water, and when the sun shines
it is as beautiful, and you know it much better than I."

"Indeed!" said the Duck, who was called Sissel, for that was her name.
"This is not a pleasant place to live, especially for a mother Duck
for whom the whole world is her home. Your room is quite all the room
you have; and it is necessary for you to go to the fields to satisfy
your hunger." And she pushed the eggs with her beak, one after the
other. "A fine feast you will have in the fields," she added, as she
reached the largest, and gave it a push with her beak.

"No fear of that," growled the old Duck. "You shall all go up to the
old mansion."

"This is all very well for you," she said. "You can stretch yourselves
out so much more easily in the fields. But for me it is very difficult
to go out of the canoes, because I have such troublesome little ones to
watch, a large head and legs to balance, and a troublesome tail to hold
tightly in the water."

"You are much better in a boat than you are on a mud-bank, for you
can hold on to me," replied Sissel. "I can take care of you, so that you
have nothing to fear; but if you are so fond of the fields, why
don't you remain here, with me, and allow your family to become like
mine, which shall then consist of five or six little ones? I will
even get up a nest in the trees for you, that you may have a comfortable
furniture."

"Furniture!" replied the old Duck, with an air of majesty; "what do
you mean by that, when you are so bare of furniture?"

"Well, then," said Sissel, "let us go to the pastor's field as the youngest
duck did with her eggs.

litter with old bones or decaying leaves because everything in his palace

Emperor's throne and to the palace!"
The King rolled his eyes and replied: "My dear, my love, remember the

The Sun King went into his son's room for a kiss, then he opened the chest.
Inside were the bones of the princesses, who had fallen upon thorny sticks,

The Emperor stood up and raised a golden crucifix. "My king," he
said, "do you realize that you are standing there before the God of Death?
And don't you think in the eyes of the Lord, you are very dead right now?
For all of heaven and earth is to die for, and in the eyes of the Lord
your golden son deserves to be killed first?"
"But my son was innocent," the Sun King whispered, "and he helped me
get the throne." The Emperor looked at him gravely. "You realize," he
said, "that I am the god in this story."
So the Sun King flew back with his son, to his own palace. As the king
and his son were alighting, he said to him: "My dear son, why did
you leave your country? You left it cold, you left it snowing and you left
it full of bones, so that you can never visit the princesses again in
their kingdom." His son kept silent.
Instead of going right to his palace, he went up the hill again to his
parents' room. He lit candles and sat there silently meditating on the
horses. His father saw him and felt strangely ashamed.
The Sun King took off his hat and bowed deeply to his father. He said:
"Forgive me, father." And he left again.
The King heard the horsemen coming, and turned to his wife and said:
"My dear, I give you back the throne of your father! I give him back his
children!"
The Queen was horrified. "You are crazy, my husband!" she screamed. "That's
our right! That's our place!"
The King thought for a while. "My queen," he said. "This sacrifice is worth
everything. You shall remain your father's queen. You shall live in your
palace with your children, and you shall bathe in your sea of fountains,
and no one shall ever spit in your garden again, or drop rotten eggs from
his cart upon your royal flowers!"
